Scheme 1 Schematic illustration of the fabrication process of Au/NiWO4, Ag/NiWO4, Cu/NiWO4. Fig 1 Fig. 2 (a) The XPS spectra of Au/NiWO4; (b) The XPS spectra of Ni2p; (c) The XPS spectra of Au4f; (d) The XPS spectra of Ag/NiWO4; (e) The XPS spectra of Ni2p, (f) The XPS spectra of Ag4f; (g) The XPS patterns of Cu/NiWO4; (h) The XPS spectra of Ni2p; (i) The XPS spectra of Cu2p; (j-l) N2 adsorption desorption isotherms and its aperture of Au/NiWO4, Ag/NiWO4, Cu/NiWO4. Fig 2 Fig. 3 (a) OER polarization curves of Au3/NiWO4, Ag3/NiWO4, Cu2/NiWO4, NiWO4, IrO2 in 1.0 M KOH; (b) Correspongding impedance diagram;(c)Correspongding Tafel slopes; (d)Activation energy curves of samples;(e)Required overpotentials to produce current densities of 10 mA cm−2, 50 mA cm−2100 mA cm−2; (f)Ladder diagram of samples; (g)1000th CV curves of Ag3/NiWO4; (h)Time-dependent current density curve of Ag3/NiWO4 at constant voltage for 300 h; (i)TOF values for OER of samples. Fig 3 Fig. 4 (a) HER polarization curves of Au3/NiWO4, Ag3/NiWO4, Cu2/NiWO4, NiWO4, 20wt % Pt/C in 1.0 M KOH; (b) Correspongding impedance diagram; (c) Correspongding Tafel slopes; (d) Plot of capacitive current measured at 10 mV cm−2 and scanning rate for samples; (e) Activation energy curve of sample; (f) Required overpotentials to produce current densities of 10 mA cm−2, 50 mA cm−2100 mA cm−2; (g) Comparison of the overpotentials to achieve the HER current density of 10 mA cm−2 for Au3/NiWO4 with reported catalysts; (h)1000th CV curves of Au3/NiWO4; (i) Time-dependent current density curve of Au3/NiWO4 at constant voltage for 150 h. Fig 4 Fig. 5 (a) HER polarization curves of Au3/NiWO4, NiWO4, Pt/C‖IrO2; (b) Comparison of voltage between Au3/NiWO4 and other electrocatalysts at 10 mA cm−2; (c) OER polarization curves of Ag3/NiWO4; (d) Required overpotentials to produce current densities of 10 mA cm−2, 50 mA cm−2, 100 mA cm−2, 120 mA cm−2; (e) Faradaic efficiency of H2 and O2 production in the HER/OER system upon operation time; (f) I-t curve of Au3/NiWO4llAg3/NiWO4 working for 100 h. Hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) is a key step in the production of hydrogen (H2) by overall water splitting, which is of great significance for the storage and conversion of renewable energy. Nevertheless, the elevated excess potential and insufficient stability of catalysts constrain their industrial applicability. Due to the poor catalytic activity of NiWO4 in alkaline solution, this study investigated the effect of IB metal (IB=Au, Ag, Cu) ion doping and its interaction with different concentrations of IBx/NiWO4 (X = 1,2,3,4 mmol) on catalytic activity to achieve stable H2 in alkaline media. In 1.0 M KOH solution, the current density is 10 mA cm−2, the Au3/NiWO4 exhibits a low overpotential is 86.11 mV, the slope of Tafel is 115.16 mV dec−1, and the overpotential of Ag3/NiWO4 is 168.41 mV, with a Tafel slope of 64.32 mV dec−1, the catalyst also showed long term stability for 150 h, the Au3/NiWO4 NF‖Au3/NiWO4 NF catalysts achieved a low voltage of 1.45 V at 10 mA cm−2 current density for 100 h. The synergistic interactions of bimetals present a novel approach for enhancing catalyst design and optimizing performance. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Interface engineering Regulation of electronic structures Overall water splitting Data availability The data that has been used is confidential. 1 Introduction As a low-carbon, zero-carbon energy, hydrogen energy considered to be the most promising clean energy in the 21st century, because hydrogen energy has high energy density, high conversion efficiency, and the product of combustion is water, which is a pollution-free energy carrier, in line with the world’s demand for non-fossil energy [1–4]. Currently, electrocatalytic cracking of water for greenest and most sustainable effective strategy to address the energy crisis, and the design and synthesis of electrocatalysts with excellent catalytic efficiency has attracted much attention abroad [5–8]. The essence of an electrocatalytic reaction is a charge transfer reaction at the interface between the electrode and the electrolyte, which is accelerated by the catalyst, and the rate of the reaction is determined by the activity of the catalyst [9,10]. Traditionally, iridium, ruthenium and platinum anchored catalysts have been effective in promoting the evolution of HER and OER, and the development of bifunctional catalysts with excellent activity has opened a new avenue for H2 synthesis [11–14]. Compared to the greatly efficient HER reaction with significant proton concentration, the cyclic anodic OER reaction has moderate dynamics and catalyst deactivation problems [15–17]. The design of low-cost and efficient electrocatalysts can accelerate the proton transfer process and provide a more theoretical basis for the construction of catalytic systems that are necessary for the sustainable development of the energy economy [18–20]. The wolframite structure of NiWO4 has been extensively studied due to its advantages of simple preparation, low cost, weak toxicity and stable properties [21,22]. The NiWO4 crystal has a monoclinic tetrahedral structure with space group P2/c, with oxygen atoms forming a twisted structure while Ni and W atoms each occupy a quarter of the oxygen octahedral gap [23,24]. The substitution of one Ni atom in the NiWO4 lattice with an IB metal atom, and the introduction of the IB metal atom to create oxygen vacancies, considerably improves the conductivity and charge transfer efficiency of NiWO4 [25]. The introduced IB metal atoms can also act as proton carriers and electron acceptors, enabling simultaneous enhancement of HER/OER catalytic activity by accelerating proton activation and metal production at elevated values [26–29]. For HER, the strong adsorption of H2 by Au elements promotes the production of active hydrogen and improves the catalytic dynamics of HER. In the OER process, Ag enhances the OER activity by promoting the formation of Ni 3 ⁺ and promoting the electron outflow of low cost [30,31]. The presence of oxygen vacancies not only modulates the electronic configuration of the catalyst and improves its charge transfer efficiency, but also acts as an active site and oxygen carrier in the catalytic reaction, thus enhancing the catalytic activity [32]. The anchoring of the IB metal enables NiWO4 to have a larger specific surface area, which effectively broadens the range of ECSA available and significantly increases the conductivity and charge transfer efficiency of the catalyst [32]. Increased catalytic active sites and improved charge transfer efficiency are responsible for the increased catalytic activity of NiWO4 [33]. By exploring the strong activity, elevated stability and hydrogen production properties of NiWO4, production costs activity is increased [34–35]. IB metal anchoring on NiWO4 is the most effective method to improve electrocatalytic performance. The dynamics of electrocatalytic reactions can be improved by tuning the electronic structure. Moreover, by optimizing the Gibbs free energy of the formed electronic intermediates through the IB metal atoms, interfacial charge transfer is affected, which facilitates catalytic reactions and thus significantly increases the electron transfer rate [36–38]. Therefore, we design a moderately efficient catalyst that introduces a unique flower-like structure anchored by ultra-low content of IB atoms into the NiWO4 material and optimizes the HER adsorption capacity in alkaline solutions. In order to improve the HER activity of Ni-based catalysts, Au, Cu and Ag contents are discussed and the effect of bulk activity on the catalytic performance is investigated. Since adsorption by H + is an important driving force leading to the leaching of monoatomic Cu from the catalyst surface, the higher the negative potential, the stronger the adsorption by H +, a competitive reaction that results in the Cu atom being partially anchored to the catalyst surface and partially dissolved in an alkaline solution, with a catalytic effect slightly lower than Au/NiWO4 and Ag/NiWO4. Au and Ag can effectively control the surface adsorption properties of NiWO4 catalysts and optimize their performance. Compared to conventional Ni-based catalysts, Au, Cu, Ag/NiWO4 catalysts have excellent hydrogen production efficiency at very low excess voltages. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materals Ni(NO3)2·6H2O (99.99 %, Macklin), HAuCl4·3H2O (99.99 %, Macklin), Ag nanowires and PEG (Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd), Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O (99.99 %, Aladdin’s reagent), NaBH4 (99 %, Sinopharm Reagent Co., LTD), N4H2·H2O (99.99 %, Titan reagent), IrO2 (Irifium Oxide) and Pt/C (20 wt %) were obtained from Aladdin. 2.2 Synthesis of the Aux/NiWO4 catalyst The synthesis route of NiWO4 is consistent with that reported in literature [38]. Au atoms anchored on NiWO4 nanomaterials is a novel synthesis process, the NiWO4 (0.05 g) nanomaterial synthesized in the previous step, which dissolved in H2O (60 mL) and CH3CH2OH (30 mL) solution. The solution was stirred and treated with ultrasound to form a uniformly yellowish solution, 0.1 mol L −1 NaBH4 (0.30 mL), 1 mmol∼4 mmol % HAuCl4·3H2O were added drop by drop and stirred for 1 h at room temperature, named Aux/NiWO4 (x = 1, 2, 3, 4). Finally, the yellow precipitate obtained at a water bath temperature of 50 °C for 3 h, then Aux/NiWO4 nanomaterials is extracted by centrifugal. 2.3 Synthesis of Agx/NiWO4 catalyst 0.04 g Ni (NO3)2·6H2O was dispersed in 20 mL deionized water, stirred at room temperature for 30 min, and then NaWO4·2H2O (0.05 g) was added. 1 mmol %∼4 mmol % silver nanowires were slowly dropped into the precursor solution, stirred for 10 min, and 0.2 mL N4H2·H2O was added, named Agx/NiWO4 (x = 1, 2, 3, 4). The sufficiently stirred sample was centrifuged to neutral with 1:2 ethanol and water and dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for 12 h. Agx/NiWO4 was obtained by calcination at 800 °C for 2 h and heating and cooling at 2 °C min−1 in N2 atmosphere. 2.4 Synthesis of Cux/NiWO4 catalyst 0.09 g NaWO4·2H2O was dispersed in 30 mL deionized water and stirred at room temperature for 30 min. After stirring, PEG (0.61 g) was added and Ni (NO3)2·6H2O (0.09 g) was added to obtain green precursor solution. Then, 1 mmol∼4 mmol % Cu(CH3COO)2·H2O was dropped into the precursor solution, stirred at 70 °C and 450 rpm for 2 h, centrifuged to neutral with 1:1 ethanol and water, dried in a vacuum oven at 60 °C for 12 h, Cux/NiWO4 (x = 1, 2, 3, 4). Doping causes an increase in the lattice constant. The atomic radii of Au, Ag and Cu are largely different from those of Ni ions in the NiWO4. When metal ions are doped into the NiWO4 lattice, the lattice distortion occurs due to the difference in atomic size, resulting in an increase of the lattice constant. An increase in the lattice constant leads to an increase in the interlunar spacing d and a decrease in the diffraction angle, resulting in a shift of the XRD diffraction peak to lower angles (Fig. 1b). The OER process is a complex fourelectron oxidation process, and it can be divided into the following four steps: (1) H − + M → M − O H * + e − (2) O H − + M − O H * → M − O * + H 2 O + e − (3) O H − + M − O * → M − O O H * + e − (4) O H − + M − O O H * → M * + O 2 + H 2 O + e − M* represents the Au,Cu and Ag atoms present on the surface of NiWO4 samples during the OER process. The active site binds to OH– to form M −,OH*, M − O* and M− OOH* intermediates, which then form O2 at the active site [50,51]. The production of these hydrogen intermediates can be further enhanced by inducing instabilities in the HOH bond, thereby increasing the OER activity [54]. Doping of IB elements can modify the band structure, raising the Fermi level and lowering the work function to activate neighboring W atoms, thus providing additional active sites for HER. These results point to a continuous electron transfer process (Ni→W→O→M) in an alkaline medium by surface oxidation of Ni to form NiOOH, promoting the oxidation of OH− to O2 [59–62]. This suggests that the synergistic effect between Au, Ag, Cu and NiWO4 promoted the formation of NiOOH, which can enhance the HER activity. The bifunctional activity of overall water splitting and hydrogen evolution in alkaline media can be ensured by surface adsorption mechanisms. In order to verify the durability of the catalyst, under the current density of 10 mA cm−2, Au/NiWO4‖Au/NiWO4, Ag/NiWO4‖Ag/NiWO4, Cu/NiWO4‖Cu/NiWO4 catalysts stability tested for both the HER and OER in 1 M KOH solution (Fig.S20∼S22), and prolonged term stability tests for 150 h. The slight degradation of Cu2/NiWO4 for 12 h at a set overpotential for both the OER and HER (η10 = 191.4 mV, I12 /I0 = 70.39 % and η10 = 160.41 mV, I12 /I0 = 53 %), Ag3/NiWO4 for 12 h at a set overpotential for both the OER and HER (η10 = 168.4 mV, I12 /I0 = 88.57 % and η10 = 171.51 mV, I12 /I0 = 70.35 %), Au3/NiWO4 for 150 h at a set overpotential for both the OER and HER (η10 = 275.4 mV, I10/I0 = 99.78 %, I50/I0 = 96.09 %, I100/I0 = 94.51 %), and a large number of bubbles can be observed on both cathode and anode surfaces during electrolysis, Ag3/NiWO4 had high stability. As shown in Fig. 5 a, when the current density was 10 mA cm−2, the voltage of Au3/NiWO4 NF‖Au3/NiWO4 NF was 1.45 V, the NiWO4 NF‖NiWO4 NF was 1.68 V, the Pt/C‖IrO2 voltage was 1.79 V. the voltage of Au3/NiWO4 (+, -) was lower than that of nanomaterials electrode systems (Fig. 5b). The polarization curves of Ag3/NiWO4 NF‖Ag3/NiWO4 NF, NiWO4 NF‖NiWO4 NF and Pt/C‖IrO2 were 1.47 V, 1.67 V and 1.78 V (Fig. 5c). The Au3/NiWO4 NF‖Au3/NiWO4 NF voltages are 1.45 V, 1.68 V, 1.88 V and 1.95 V at a current density of 10, 50, 100 and 120 mA cm−2, respectively. Which was comparable to the performance of most recently developed dual function total water splitting electrocatalysts (Fig. 5d, Table.S7). The current O2 rate of Au3/NiWO4 NF‖Au3/NiWO4 NF is 99.94 %, the current H2 rate was 99.91 % (Fig. 5e). The excellent catalytic performance attributed to the following factors:(i) The IB metal- anchored tungstate not only improves its own metallic properties and internal conductivity, but also provides a good surface electronic structure to enhance its catalytic activity [63]. At the same time, it can induce changes in the surface actives sites, making it easier to achieve thermodynamic adsorption of hydrogen/oxygen at the catalyst surface. At the same time, electron transfer between precious metals is more likely to increase electron conduction, reducing the energy barrier of the reactant adsorption-desorption process and thus enhancing its electrostatic activity. (ii) The introduction of heteroatoms can not only regulate the coordination environment of nickel-based octahedral groups, but also provide a certain steric hindrance to alleviate the agglomeration phenomenon in the process of overall water splitting [64]. (iii) The formation of nano-multilayer structures around metal sites is conducive to the mass transfer of catalytic reactions and the exposure of active sites [65,66]. Based on the above analysis, the synergistic effect between the active bimetallic tungstate and the metal doping played a decisive role in improving the electrocatalytic performance of bimetallic Ni based materials. (M=Au, Ag, Cu)/NiWO4 provides an efficient route to the development and utilization of clean and renewable energy sources as a high-efficiency, low-cost, electrochemically stable dual-function catalyst. This indicated that Au3/NiWO4 NF‖Ag3/NiWO4 NF had excellent long-term stability in the process of overall water splitting. Fig. 5f showed the η10 at 1 M KOH, and the electrolytic cell can operate stable for 100 h. DFT used to demonstrate the influence of the effect interface of heterojunction on catalytic performance displayed in Fig. 6 . According to HRTEM results, Cu2O (111) and NiWO4(110) were catalytic interfaces. The Gibbs free energy shift was calculated at each reaction step of the alkaline OER for Cu/NiWO4. The binding energies indicate that Cu2O and NiWO4 are bound by chemical bonds rather than weak vander Waals forces. The charge between Cu and O atoms in Cu2O forms a Cu-O bond through the interface, which allowed Cu to enter the heterojunction with a stronger positive charge than in the original Cu2O. According to the mechanism of OER four electron transfer reaction, the stable structures of M/NiWO4 interacting with the oxygen-containing intermediate states (OH*, O* and OOH*) generated during the reaction were determined, respectively [67–69]. Fig. 6a was the ΔGH* diagram of oxygen-containing intermediate states generated during OER adsorption at different sites of Cu/NiWO4 at an applied voltage of 1.23 V. As shown in Fig. 6b, red and silver sticks represent *OH, red balls represent oxygen atoms, the blue balls represent Cu atoms. Ag3/NiWO4 exhibits the highest OER catalytic activity, presumably because the Au3/NiWO4 and Cu2/NiWO4 systems have stronger adsorption onto oxygen-containing intermediates, making subsequent reactions or gas dissociation more difficult. Therefore, in the catalytic OER process, the catalyst for the adsorption of oxygen intermediate state requires a suitable adsorption energy (Fig. 6c). HER electrocatalytic mechanism diagram for Au/NiWO4 constructed (Fig. 6d). It performs a series of DFT calculations using VASP software. *H and *2H are connected to nickel atoms to construct a stable structure after the interaction of H* generated during the reaction between Au/NiWO4 and HER. As shown in Fig. 6e, indicating that H* has a significant activity on Au/NiWO4. ΔGH* on Au/NiWO4 is closer to zero. Theoretical calculations showed that a certain amount of Au atom can enhance the HER catalytic activity. It is known that Ni2+ and W6+ ions in the NiWO4 structure form NiO6 octahedra and WO6 octahedra with oxygen, respectively. W6+ can not participate in redox reactions and their essential role is to enhance the conductivity and electrochemical properties of NiWO4 electrocatalysts. After OH− ions diffuse to the electrocatalyst, they interact with oxygen atoms in the NiO6 cluster during charging to form NiOOH structures and release electrons (Fig. 6f). It has been shown that IB group electron transport is closely related to crystal structure distortions. When the degree of crystal structure distortion is relatively low, as in NiOOH. Its unoccupied d z 2 orbit coincides exactly with the a1g* orbit. Since the a1g* band is formed by the hybridization of metal 4 s and O 2p orbitals, according to the filling order of Ni atomic orbitals, the electron transfer from oxygen band to d z 2 orbitals cannot be realized. The doping regime of Au can be improved when the degree of crystal structure distortion is relatively steep. The oxygen band can be transferred to the metal d z 2 orbital electron, which is conducive to the hydrogen evolution reaction, as shown in Fig. 7 a. Ni as the active site can capture OH− from water, and alter the reaction speed step from OOH* generate to O2 by conventional adsorbent evolution mechanism (AEM), which considerably reduces the reaction energy barrier and significantly improves the catalytic activity without sacrificing stability. At the same time, Ag can dynamically provide electrons to Ni in the reaction under synergistic multiple mechanisms, which inhibits excessive oxidation and dissociation of active sites and further improves catalytic stability (Fig. 7b). The effect of Au, Ag, and Cu doping on the electronic configuration and catalytic activity of NiWO4 has been discussed in terms of the splitting pattern of Ni2+in the crystal field. As shown in Fig. 8 , consistent with the results verified by XPS, doping of group IB metals can lead to the oxidation of Ni2+ in the tungstate lattice to form Ni3+ ions, and the corresponding electronic configuration of Ni3+ is ( t 2 g 6 e g 1 ). This asymmetric electronic configuration is prone to lattice distortions in the octahedral field. In addition, high-energy eg orbitals can form d x 2 − y 2 and d z 2 , and empty high-energy orbitals act as acceptor orbitals to receive electron fillings from lone pairs of OH−, thus enhancing the catalytic activity of oxygen evolution reactions. As shown in formula (2), as the active center in alkaline solution, the empty orbitals of Ni3+ are more easily hybrid with the full 2p orbitals of oxygen atoms. This accelerates electron transfer, whereas Ni2+ has no additional empty orbitals and requires additional energy to accommodate lone pairs of OH-electrons. Therefore, the presence of Au, Ag and Cu also plays a crucial role in improving the catalyst performance of NiWO4: (1) The doping of IB metal leads to the synergistic effect of bimetallic active sites, which is conducive to the formation of catalytic active intermediates; (2) Anchored IB metal ions in NiWO4 lattice are conducive to the release of O2 molecules, which may be caused by the synergistic effect of IB metal ions and Ni2+; (3) The presence of anchored IB metal ions in the NiWO4 lattice enhances the elevated conductivity of the catalytic material and also improves the electron transfer at the electrode/electrolyte interface; (4) Due to the flow-like structure of NiWO4, additional active sites are exposed, and the introduction of Au nanoparticles avoids the easy agglomeration of materials, enhances the stability of HER, and the synergistic effect is conducive to the improvement of catalytic activity; (5) There is orbital overlap between d orbital of Ag and Ni, which also verifies the synergistic effect of Ag and Ni. Moreover, the introduction of Ag nanowires makes the catalyst more conductive, with a larger active area and higher Ni3+, which is also responsible for the better OER activity. In order to further explore the crystal structure of Au, Ag, Cu@NiWO4 nanocrystals after testing, XRD tests were performed. As shown in Fig.S23, there are characteristic diffraction peaks at 2θ =15.62°,19.28°,23.97°,24.92°,30.93°and 36.57°, corresponding to the (010), (100), (011), (110), (−111), (002) crystal planes of diffraction, respectively. All XRD peaks are consistent with the crystal system NiWO4 (JCPDS:15–0755), the diffraction peaks are significantly weakened, and the diffraction angle is partially offset, indicating that after electrocatalytic test, although the sample morphology is damaged, the crystal structure is still stable, which is consistent with the electrocatalytic property, and also the reason for the relatively lengthy stability of catalytic evolution energy (Fig.S23a). In order to additionally observe the morphology of the tested samples, it was found that due to the use of naphthol reagents, the catalyst was wrapped in a membrane-like structure, and the surface and fault were wire-drawn structures, so the morphology of the catalyst could not be accurately observed (Fig.S23b∼Fig. 23f). 4. Conclusion In this study, through the double modulation of Au, Ag, Cu/NiWO4, both the metal site and the oxygen active site of the catalyst were activated, and the adsorption of OER active intermediates under the mechanism of adsorbent evolution was effectively optimized, and a bifunctional catalyst with metal active site and lattice oxygen compatibility mechanism was constructed. In alkaline media, Ag3/NiWO4 exhibited excellent OER performance with the potential of 168.41 mV at a current density of 10 mA cm−2. Au3/NiWO4 showed excellent HER performance with the potential of 86.11 mV. The Au3/NiWO4@NF‖Au3/NiWO4-@NF consisted of double electrodes are 1.448 V and used for overall water splitting, and stability maintained up to 100 h. The designed Au, Ag, Cu/NiWO4 catalysts maximize the use of surfaces active sites and show excellent HER/OER catalytic activity and stability under cooperative optimization of multiple mechanisms. This work provides fresh ideas for the design of modern efficient OER catalysts. CRediT authorship contribution statement Min Yang: Writing – original draft, Resources, Project administration. coredata.dc:description: Hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) is a key step in the production of hydrogen (H2) by overall water splitting, which is of great significance for the storage and conversion of renewable energy. Nevertheless, the elevated excess potential and insufficient stability of catalysts constrain their industrial applicability. Due to the poor catalytic activity of NiWO4 in alkaline solution, this study investigated the effect of IB metal (IB=Au, Ag, Cu) ion doping and its interaction with different concentrations of IBx/NiWO4 (X = 1,2,3,4 mmol) on catalytic activity to achieve stable H2 in alkaline media. In 1.0 M KOH solution, the current density is 10 mA cm−2, the Au3/NiWO4 exhibits a low overpotential is 86.11 mV, the slope of Tafel is 115.16 mV dec−1, and the overpotential of Ag3/NiWO4 is 168.41 mV, with a Tafel slope of 64.32 mV dec−1, the catalyst also showed long term stability for 150 h, the Au3/NiWO4 NF‖Au3/NiWO4 NF catalysts achieved a low voltage of 1.45 V at 10 mA cm−2 current density for 100 h. The synergistic interactions of bimetals present a novel approach for enhancing catalyst design and optimizing performance.
